dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we always talk about what we eat, right? But it's wild how much our food system, like, impacts the entire planet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we always talk about what we eat, right? But it's wild how much our food system, like, impacts the entire planet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The way we produce and consume this food, meanwhile, damages Earths life-support system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty staggering. I was just reading this article, um, that pointed out it's responsible for about a quarter of all greenhouse gas emissions. And, like, a huge driver of land use change, biodiversity loss...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty staggering. I was just reading this article, um, that pointed out it's responsible for about a quarter of all greenhouse gas emissions. And, like, a huge driver of land use change, biodiversity loss...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It accounts for about one-quarter of greenhouse-gas emissions and is the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, and water extraction, leaving rivers dried out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! And you see all these books on healthy eating, so clearly people *want* to eat better. But, uh, actual action from countries seems really slow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And you see all these books on healthy eating, so clearly people want to eat better. But, uh, actual action from countries seems really slow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The sheer volume of books on healthy eating and weight loss suggests that people want to move to healthier diets. But few countries are taking action to improve diets and preserve the environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And the big question is, can we even *feed* everyone sustainably by 2050? Like, 15 billion people? That's a lot of mouths.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And the big question is, can we even feed everyone sustainably by twenty fifty? Like, fifteen billion people? That's a lot of mouths.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The big question is whether we can sustainably provide a healthy diet to a global population that is projected to reach ten billion by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's exactly it. And that's where this EAT-Lancet Commission came in. They had, what, 37 scientists from 17 countries, including the author of this piece, trying to figure that out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's exactly it. And that's where this E A T-Lancet Commission came in. They had, what, thirty seven scientists from seventeen countries, including the author of this piece, trying to figure that out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Two years ago, the EAT-Lancet Commission, comprising 37 scientists from 16 countries me included set out to provide an answer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they basically mapped out what a healthy diet looks like *and* what that means for global food production sustainably. Their report, uh, just came out in the Journal of American Medicine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they basically mapped out what a healthy diet looks like and what that means for global food production sustainably. Their report, uh, just came out in the Journal of American Medicine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Commission published its findings in January in the medical journal The Lancet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: And it sounds like it really hit a nerve, right? Over 2,000 stories in the media already. [overlaps] Because it affects everyone...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it sounds like it really hit a nerve, right? Over two thousand stories in the media already. Because it affects everyone...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With more than 5,000 stories about the report already in the international media, its release clearly has hit a nerve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh yeah, definitely. Farmers, food companies, us consumers. But the big takeaway, supported by tons of evidence, is that feeding ten billion people sustainably *is* possible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, definitely. Farmers, food companies, us consumers. But the big takeaway, supported by tons of evidence, is that feeding ten billion people sustainably is possible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our main conclusion, supported by reams of peer-reviewed evidence, is that feeding ten billion people on a sustainable planet is possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it's possible, but not without a massive overhaul. Like, they identified three really big things we need to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so it's possible, but not without a massive overhaul. Like, they identified three really big things we need to do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The world must do three big things in particular.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. First, we've gotta halve food waste by 2050. Second, move to more efficient and sustainable production, investing in healthier crops. And third, and this is a big one, eat more fruits, veggies, nuts, legumes... and cut down on dairy and red meat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. First, we've gotta halve food waste by twenty fifty. Second, move to more efficient and sustainable production, investing in healthier crops. And third, and this is a big one, eat more fruits, veggies, nuts, legumes... and cut down on dairy and red meat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It needs to halve the amount of food waste by 2050. It must move to more efficient and sustainable production systems and invest more in healthier crops. And people need to eat more fruit, vegetables, nuts, and legumes and reduce their dairy and red-meat consumption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, cutting down on red meat significantly. That's a huge shift for a lot of cultures. I mean, they talk about a typical weekly plan with, like, one hamburger, maybe two chicken dishes, five fish meals... and the rest plant-based.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, cutting down on red meat significantly. That's a huge shift for a lot of cultures. I mean, they talk about a typical weekly plan with, like, one hamburger, maybe two chicken dishes, five fish meals... and the rest plant-based.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A typical weekly meal plan under our proposal might include a hamburger, a couple of chicken dishes, and one or two fish meals, with the others being plant-based.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a big change, but they stress it's super flexible. It's not about being strictly vegan or vegetarian, though those fit perfectly. It's more about, um, using animal products as flavorings sometimes, rather than the main event.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a big change, but they stress it's super flexible. It's not about being strictly vegan or vegetarian, though those fit perfectly. It's more about, um, using animal products as flavorings sometimes, rather than the main event.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We went to great lengths to stress that this diet is flexible and can be adapted to different cultures and different produce... Vegetarian or vegan diets also fall entirely within our food group ranges. Alternatively, people might use animal-based foods as flavorings rather than as the main part of a meal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, a Mediterranean diet from a generation ago, with tons of fresh produce, is actually pretty similar to what they're recommending. It's adaptable to any culture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, a Mediterranean diet from a generation ago, with tons of fresh produce, is actually pretty similar to what they're recommending. It's adaptable to any culture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The common Mediterranean diet of a generation ago, with plenty of fresh vegetables and fruit, has much in common with our planetary health diet. Similarly, those of us in Nordic countries used to consume less meat and fewer dairy products, in line with the Commissions recommendation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But it's not just *what* we eat, it's also *how* we produce it. They say shifting our diets won't be enough if we don't improve production systems, no matter if you're a big farm or a small organic one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But it's not just what we eat, it's also how we produce it. They say shifting our diets won't be enough if we don't improve production systems, no matter if you're a big farm or a small organic one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is important to recognize that shifting to the planetary health diet will not in itself lead to sustainable production. We also need to improve how we produce what we eat. ... Whether food producers operate large businesses, intensive farms, smallholdings, or organic farms, all can support the dietary and sustainability transition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: And, you know, while there's been a lot of support for these ideas, some industry groups are pushing back, saying, like, 'Oh, it's not feasible for large populations.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, you know, while there's been a lot of support for these ideas, some industry groups are pushing back, saying, like, 'Oh, it's not feasible for large populations.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the report was launched, the Commission has been overwhelmed by the support shown for its conclusions. At the same time, several industry groups and other commentators have argued... Some argue that it simply is not feasible for large populations to adopt healthy, sustainable diets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a common argument, but we've seen diets change dramatically over decades. The point of this report, really, is to start that conversation. To get everyone involved – from farmers to consumers – thinking about what we'll be eating and how we'll produce it in 10, 20, 30 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a common argument, but we've seen diets change dramatically over decades. The point of this report, really, is to start that conversation. To get everyone involved - from farmers to consumers - thinking about what we'll be eating and how we'll produce it in ten, twenty, thirty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Globally, however, we can trace how diets have changed dramatically in recent decades. Now, we want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders from farmers to consumers about what we will be eating, and how we produce it, ten, 20, and 30 years from now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because ultimately, a healthier planet and healthier us, um, really depend on it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because ultimately, a healthier planet and healthier us, um, really depend on it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If we can do that, our food system can benefit, rather than harm, our own health and that of the planet.
